entry.et: Middle English, from Middle French, from Latin contentus, from past participle of continēre to hold in, contain contain

def.dt: :contented satisfied was content with her life as it was
:to limit (oneself) in requirements, desires, or actions

entry.et: Middle English, from Latin contentus, past participle of continēre to contain

def.dt: :something contained usually used in plural the jar's contents the drawer's contents
:the topics or matter treated in a written work table of contents
:the principal substance (as written matter, illustrations, or music) offered by a World Wide Web site Internet users have evolved an ethos of free content in the Internet Ben Gerson
:the events, physical detail, and information in a work of art compare form 10b
:the matter dealt with in a field of study
:a part, element, or complex of parts

:analysis of the manifest and latent content of a body of communicated material (as a book or film) through a classification, tabulation, and evaluation of its key symbols and themes in order to ascertain its meaning and probable effect
:a word that primarily expresses lexical meaning compare function word
